headline: DeWine declares Ukrainian 'Day of Prayer,' orders Ohio to stop selling Russian vodka
author: Céilí Doyle
sentences: The agency estimates there are roughly 6,400 bottles of vodka made by Russian Standard currently for sale in Ohio's 487 liquor agencies across the state, according to the governor's office, and the Ohio Division of Liquor Control informed all retailers that they must pull all of those bottles from their shelves.

Russian invasion:Zelensky says he's open to talks with Russia; EU support for Ukraine grows - live updates
"We condemn this violence and threats to innocent civilians," DeWine and Lt. Gov Jon Husted wrote in their decree.
Over 200 hundred Ohioans — many Ukrainian-Americans — gathered at the Ohio Statehouse Downtown on Saturday to protest Russian President Vladimir Putin' decision to attack Ukraine.
The governor also directed the state's department of commerce to stop buying and selling Russian Standard vodka, the only overseas Russian vodka distillery sold in Ohio.
Meanwhile, across the city at Lower.com field, a Dublin resident unfurled a Ukrainian flag in support ahead of the Columbus Crew game against the Vancouver Whitecaps.
Mike DeWine declared Sunday, Feb. 27 a "Day of Prayer" for Ukraine across Ohio as a full-scale Russian invasion of its eastern European neighbor is underway.
Editor's note: A previous version of this story incorrectly stated that Saturday, Feb. 26 is the "Day of Prayer."
The Ukrainian flag will also fly at the Ohio Statehouse and in the governor's residence in Bexley, DeWine said.
Céilí Doyle is a Report for America corps member and covers rural issues in Ohio for The Dispatch.
Your donation to match our RFA grant helps keep her writing stories like this one.

Signs of support for Ukraine were visible across Columbus.
